case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Harkisondas Ratilal

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 240 of 1955 by special leave from Bombay High Court judgment dated September 3, 1953 in Income-tax Reference No. 15 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 240 of 1955. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 3, 1953, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 15 of 1953.

facts.text: Appeal by the Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay against Bombay High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by the Commissioner of Incometax, Bombay, against the judgment of the High Court at Bombay given on a reference under s. 60 2  of the Income-tax Act

facts.text: Assessment year concerned was 1948-49, accounting year 2003 Sambat.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment year companycerned was 1948-49, the accounting year being 2003 Sambat.

facts.text: Bhavnagar was a ruling State outside British India at relevant time.

anchor.surface_text: At the relevant time, Bhavnagar was a ruling State and therefore outside British India.

facts.text: Assessee and brother Gordhandas had large sums in deposit with Bhavnagar Mills from earlier profits earned there.

anchor.surface_text: There was a mill there which we shall, for brevity, call the Bhavnagar Mills. The assessee and his brother Gordhandas had large sums in deposit with the Bhavnagar Mills. These sums were profits earlier earned by the assessee and his brother in Bhavnagar.

facts.text: Deposits belonged to assessee and brother in equal shares.

anchor.surface_text: The amounts deposited belonged to the assessee and his brother in equal shares,

facts.text: Bhavnagar Mills account showed Rs. 50,000 paid to Harkisondas Ratilal on April 7, 1947 and same to Dilipkumar Trikamlal.

anchor.surface_text: This account showed that on April 7, 1947, a sum of Rs. 50,000/- had been paid out to Harkisondas Ratilal and another sum of the same amount to Dilipkumar Trikamlal.

facts.text: Bombay Mills account showed Rs. 50,000 received from Harkisondas Ratilal on April 3, 1947 and same from Dilipkumar Trikamlal.

anchor.surface_text: There is another mill in Bombay which we shall call the Bombay Mills. The account of the Bombay Mills showed that on April 3, 1947, Rs. 50,000/- had been received from each of Harkisondas Ratilal and Dilipkumar Trikamlal.

facts.text: Harkisondas Ratilal and Dilipkumar Trikamlal were benamidars for assessee and brother.

anchor.surface_text: Harkisondas Ratilal and Dilipkumar Trikamlal were the benamidars for the assessee and his brother

facts.text: Assessee and brother in full control of both Bhavnagar Mills and Bombay Mills.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee and his brother were in full companytrol of both the Bhavnagar Mills and the Bombay Mills.

facts.text: Tribunal concluded there was remittance of assessee's profits Rs. 50,000 from Bhavnagar to Bombay taxable under s.4(1)(b)(iii).

anchor.surface_text: On these facts the Tribunal had companye to the companyclusion that there had been a remittance of the assessees profits from Bhavnagar to Bombay, namely, Rs. 50,000/- being half of the amounts mentioned above, on account of his share and such remittance was taxable tinder s. 4 1   b   iii .

facts.text: Bombay High Court answered the question in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter, the High Court answered the question referred in the negative.

facts.text: Supreme Court referred case back to Tribunal on April 24, 1958 for further statement.

anchor.surface_text: In this matter by our order made on April 24, 1958, we had referred the case back to the Tribunal to submit a further statement of case on certain questions.

facts.text: Bhavnagar Mills had account in Bank of India Limited at Bombay branch.

anchor.surface_text: The Bhavnagar Mills had an account in the Bank of India Limited at one of its Bombay Branches.

facts.text: Cheque book for that account with assessee who had power to operate on behalf of Bhavnagar Mills.

anchor.surface_text: A cheque book in respect of this account was with the assessee who had power to operate it on behalf of the Bhavnagar Mills.

facts.text: Assessee drew cheque on April 3, 1947 in Bombay on Bhavnagar Mills account in Bank of India, in favour of self.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee acting on behalf of the Bhavnagar Mills drew a cheque on the Bhavnagar Mills aforesaid account in the Bank of India Limited on April 3, 1947, in favour of self. This was done in Bombay.

facts.text: Cheque handed by assessee to Bombay Mills in Bombay for credit to Harkison Ratilal and Dilipkumar Trikamlal accounts.

anchor.surface_text: This cheque was handed over by the assessee to the Bombay Mills in Bombay for being credited in the account of the Bombay Mills in the names of Harkison Ratilal and Dilipkumar Trikamlal

facts.text: Bombay Mills presented cheque to another Bank of India branch in Bombay on April 3, 1947; entries made April 5, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay Mills on the same date presented this cheque to another branch of the Bank of India Ltd. in Bombay where they had an account, for deposit in that account. The actual entries in the books of the different branches of the Bank were made on April 5, 1947.

facts.text: Bombay Mills credited moneys to Harkison Ratilal and Dilipkumar Trikamlal in own books.

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay Mills also made entries in their own books crediting the moneys received on the cheque, to Harkison Ratilal and Dilipkumar Trikamlal.

facts.text: Assessee instructed Bhavnagar Mills to debit joint account Rs. 1,00,000 on April 7, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee in his turn instructed the Bhavnagar Mills to debit the joint account of himself and his brother with it in the sum of Rs. 1 lac as having been paid to Harkison Ratilal and Dilipkumar Trikamlal. This entry was actually made a little later, namely on April 7, 1947.

facts.text: Nothing done at Bhavnagar regarding the transaction.

anchor.surface_text: The facts number found would show that numberhing had been done at Bhavnagar.

facts.text: Assessee utilised moneys from Bhavnagar Mills to advance to Bombay Mills as Bombay Mills needed moneys.

anchor.surface_text: It was also found that as the Bombay Mills needed moneys and the assessee had money with the Bhavnagar Mills, he utilised these latter moneys for an advance being made by him out of it to the Bombay Mills,

facts.text: Assessee was resident of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee, who is the respondent in this appeal, was a resident of Bombay.

facts.text: Transactions took place in April 1947.

anchor.surface_text: These transactions took place in April 1947.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 3, 1953,

concepts.interpretation: Under s.4(1)(a), receipt means first receipt; subsequent remittance not receipt again. Distinguished for s.4(1)(b)(iii).

issues.text: Whether, in any event, on the facts found by the Tribunal, there was any remittance by the petitioner to Bombay within the meaning of and assessable under s. 4(1)(b)(iii) of the Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: assessable under s. 4 1   b   iii  of the Income-tax Act,. The assessment year companycerned was 1948-49, the accounting year being 2003 Sambat. The facts found may number be stated. At the relevant time, Bhavnagar was a ruling State and therefore outside British India. There was a mill there which we shall, for brevity, call the Bhavnagar Mills.

issues.text: whether on these facts it can be said that income had been brought into or received in Bombay by the assessee

anchor.surface_text: chargeable to income-tax under s. 3 of the Act. It is divided into three parts. The first part, which is el.  a  provides that all income, profits and gains received or deemed to be received in the taxable territories in such year by or on behalf of such person will be included in the taxable income.

issues.text: Whether the receipt in s.4(1)(b)(iii) must be the first receipt like under clause (a)

anchor.surface_text: It has been held under this clause that receipt must be the first receipt in the taxable territories and if income etc. has been received elsewhere in the same year and is then brought into the taxable territories

issues.text: Whether income is taxable under s.4(1)(b)(iii) only if brought into or received in the taxable territories by the assessee himself and not on his behalf or by indirect method

anchor.surface_text: 4.  1  Subject to the provisions of this Act, the total income of any previous year of any person includes all income, profits and gains from whatever source derived which-  a are received

issues.text: Whether the assessee can be said to have brought into or received this income in Bombay within the meaning of sub-cl. (iii) of s. 4(1)(b)

anchor.surface_text: under s. 4 1  b  iii  of the Income-tax Act, 1922. That section so fair as is material is in these terms S4.  1  Subject to the provisions of this Act,

arguments.claim: There had been a remittance of the assessee's profits from Bhavnagar to Bombay, namely Rs. 50,000, taxable under s.4(1)(b)(iii)

anchor.surface_text: On these facts the Tribunal had come to the conclusion that there had been a remittance of the assessees profits from Bhavnagar to Bombay, namely, Rs. 50,000/- being half of the amounts mentioned above, on account of his share and such remittance was taxable tinder s. 4 1   b   iii .

arguments.court_reasoning: Facts show receipt in Bombay by drawing cheque on Bombay bank and crediting to benamidars

arguments.claim: Income taxable only when brought into or received in taxable territory by assessee himself, not on behalf; facts show substitution of debtors only

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that under the section income is taxable only when it is brought into or received in the taxable territory by the assessee himself and not when it is so brought into or received on behalf of the assessee and that all that the facts found by the Tribunal showed was that the assessee disposed of his accumulated income in Bhavnagar by directing his debtor, the Bhavnagar Mills, to pay an amount not to himself but to a third party, namely, the Bombay Mills.

arguments.court_reasoning: Receipt by assessee via indirect method; cites Bipin Lal precedent

arguments.claim: Even on substitution basis, Bombay Mills crediting amount to assessee constitutes receipt by assessee himself in Bombay before advancing

anchor.surface_text: When the appeal was heard by us on the earlier occasion, the learned Advocate for the appellant contended that even on the basis on which the High Court had proceeded, namely, that there was only a substitution of one debtor for another, it has to be said that the money was received by the assessee himself in Bombay. The contention was that the respondent could not become a creditor of the Bombay Mills unless he advanced the moneys to them.

arguments.court_reasoning: With additional facts, confirmed receipt via cheque drawing in Bombay

arguments.claim: No evidence agreement or cheque movement; possibly all done in Bhavnagar, so notional receipt and advance there, money brought by Bombay Mills

anchor.surface_text: The learned advocate for the assessee said in answer to this contention that there was nothing to show that the agreement for the advance of the money by the assessee to the Bombay Mills had not been made at Bhavnagar. He also said that there was nothing to show as to how the money or the cheque came from Bhavnagar to Bombay and that it might have been that it was agreed between the assessee and the Bombay Mills at Bhavnagar

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ls to debit the joint account of himself and his brother with it in the sum of Rs. 1 lac as having been paid to Harkison Ratilal and Dilipkumar Trikam

arguments.court_reasoning: Tribunal found all transactions in Bombay, nothing done at Bhavnagar

arguments.claim: Under cl.(a), receipt means first receipt in taxable territories; applies to (b)(iii) as same words 'received'

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak for the respondent however argues that the words in cl. b iii are the same as in cl. a , namely, are received and therefore the receipt in cl. b iii must also be the first receipt.

arguments.court_reasoning: Words not terms of art; context differs; (b)(iii) for prior income already received outside

arguments.claim: Cl.(a) requires first receipt (citing Keshav Mills); income received once cannot be received again
arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees received in Bhavnagar but liable as 'brought into' Bombay

arguments.claim: Scheme of s.4(1): cl.(a) first receipt irrespective of residence; distinguishes for resident's prior foreign income in (b)(iii)

anchor.surface_text: The relevant portion of the section is in these terms - 4. 1 Subject to the provisions of this Act, the total income of any previous year of any person includes all income, profits and gains from whatever source derived which- a are received or are deemed to be received in the taxable territories in such year by or on behalf of such person, or b if such person is resident in the taxable territories during such year,-

arguments.claim: In cl.(b)(iii), 'received' need not be first receipt unlike cl.(a); context differs as for pre-previous year foreign income already received outside
Having accrued/arisen outside implies already received outside; (b)(iii) taxes bringing/receipt of such prior income
On facts, assessee received income in Bombay by drawing cheque on Bhavnagar Mills' Bombay bank account in favour of self, handing to Bombay Mills for credit to benamidars
Indirect method of receipt still counts as receipt 'by him'; cites Bipin Lal where direction to debtor to pay creditor constituted receipt
Assessee received income in Bhavnagar already, cannot receive again in Bombay; 'received' same meaning as cl.(a)
arguments.court_reasoning: Liable under 'brought into' even if not receipt

arguments.claim: Received in Bhavnagar but brought into Bombay by discharging debt via cheque in Bombay, acquiring new debt from Bombay Mills
Bringing income does not require unchanged shape; debt discharge in taxable territories = bringing income (analogies: coins, draft)

holdings.text: The respondent is liable to pay income-tax on the sum of Rs. 50,000/- under s. 4(1)(b)(iii) of the Act and the question framed therefore must be answered in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the respondent is liable to pay incometax on the sum of Rs. 50,000/- under s. 4 1  b  iii  of the Act and the question framed therefore must be answered in the affirmative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show assessee drew cheque in Bombay on Bhavnagar Mills' Bombay bank account in favour of self, handed to Bombay Mills for credit to benamidars, constituting receipt of prior foreign income in taxable territories by resident assessee.

holdings.text: For the purpose of cl. (b)(iii) the receiving in the taxable territories need not be the first receipt.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, for the purpose of cl.  b  iii  the receiving in the taxable territories need number be the first receipt. We shall later companysider what will be the effect of this interpretation on the facts of this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of s.4(1): cl.(a) concerns first receipt of current year income regardless of residence; cl.(b)(iii) taxes remittance of pre-year foreign income already received outside, so 'received' not limited to first receipt; distinguishes Keshav Mills.

holdings.text: When cl. (b)(iii) speaks of income etc. having accrued or arisen without the taxable territories it is implicit that such income had already been received there.

anchor.surface_text: This is theoretically possible but in our opinion it is clear that when el.  b  iii  speaks of income etc. having accrued or arisen, without the taxable territories it is implicit in it further that such income etc. having accrued or arisen without the taxable territories had already been received there.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Context of cl.(b)(iii) for income accrued after 1933 but before previous year implies prior receipt outside; otherwise clause purposeless as unlikely unreceived after years.

holdings.text: There was clearly receipt in the previous year of income etc. which had accrued to the respondent outside the taxable territories before the previous year.

anchor.surface_text: There was thus clearly receipt in the previous year of income etc. which had accrued to the respondent outside the taxable territories before the previous year and he would therefore be chargeable under s. 3 of the Act with respect to this amount.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee, resident in Bombay, drew cheque on Bhavnagar Mills' Bombay bank account, received via crediting to benamidars in Bombay Mills.

holdings.text: The indirect method employed in this case for receiving the money would nevertheless make it a receipt by the respondent himself.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Drawing cheque in favour of self and crediting via benamidars is receipt by assessee; analogous to directing debtor to pay creditor (Bipin Lal).

holdings.text: It is unnecessary to consider whether the words 'brought into the taxable territories by him' mean that the income must be brought in by the person himself.

anchor.surface_text: We have held that this is a case of receipt by the respondent in the taxable territories it is therefore unnecessary to companysider in the present case whether the words brought into the taxable territories by him mean that the income must be brought in by the person himself as held by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since case decided on 'received', no need to decide 'brought into'.

holdings.text: The assessee had received the income in Bhavnagar and could not receive it again in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to me that this companytention is well founded. This Court has held that Once an amount is received as income, any remittance or transmission of the amount to another place does number result in I receipt

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurring opinion: 'received' in (b)(iii) means first receipt like cl.(a) (Keshav Mills); income received once cannot be received again.

holdings.text: The assessee brought the income into Bombay by discharging the Bhavnagar debt via cheque in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: If, however, the assessee did number receive the income in Bombay, it seems clear to me that he brought into Bombay that income. He got in Bombay an amount which he had earlier received in Bhavnagar as income

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurring: Changed shape to debt discharged in taxable territories equals bringing income; analogies to coins, draft.

precedents.case_name: Keshav Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: receipt under clause (a) must be the first receipt in the taxable territories
precedents.cited_holding: if income etc. has been received elsewhere in the same year and is then brought into the taxable territories it should not be considered to be income etc. received in such year in the taxable territories

anchor.surface_text: Keshav Mills case

precedents.case_name: Keshav Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: receipt in cl. (a) means the first receipt

precedents.citation: Keshav Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income- tax, Bombay

anchor.surface_text: Keshav Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income- tax, Bombay

precedents.case_name: Keshav Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: once an amount is received as income, any remittance or transmission does not result in a receipt at the other place under cl. (a)
precedents.cited_holding: Once an amount is received as income, any remittance or transmission of the amount to another place does not result in receipt within the meaning of this clause at the other place

anchor.surface_text: Keshav Mills case

precedents.case_name: Keshav Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: the word 'received' in s. 4(1)(a) meant the first receipt after accrual

precedents.citation: Bipin Lal Kuthiala v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab

anchor.surface_text: Bipin Lal Kuthiala v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab

precedents.case_name: Bipin Lal Kuthiala v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: indirect method of directing debtor outside taxable territories to pay creditor inside constitutes receipt inside
precedents.cited_holding: the assessee directed his debtor in Jubbal (outside) to pay money to his creditor in British India; held receipt of income in British India though indirect

precedents.citation: Sundar Das v. Collector of Gujrat

anchor.surface_text: Sundar Das v. Collector of Gujrat

precedents.case_name: Sundar Das v. Collector of Gujrat
precedents.cited_proposition: income remaining under assessee's control cannot be received again

precedents.citation: Board of Revenue v. Ripon Press

anchor.surface_text: Board of Revenue v. Ripon Press

precedents.case_name: Board of Revenue v. Ripon Press
precedents.cited_proposition: cannot receive the same sum of money qua income twice, once outside and once inside
precedents.cited_holding: you cannot receive the same sum of money qua income twice over, once outside British India and once inside it

precedents.citation: Gresham Life Assurance Society Ltd. v. Bishop

anchor.surface_text: Gresham Life Assurance Society Ltd. v. Bishop

precedents.case_name: Gresham Life Assurance Society Ltd. v. Bishop
precedents.cited_proposition: income may be conceived in other forms than money; anything representing and producing money treated as income by businessmen

anchor.surface_text: Tennant v. Smith

precedents.cited_proposition: income may be in other forms than money
